instruction: Can the in situ visible and near infrared (Vis-NIR) spectroscopy method accurately determine soil salinity (SS) in arid and semi-arid regions, and how does it compare to traditional methods in terms of accuracy?
Output:

The past study collected Vis-NIR in situ spectral and lab-measured SS data from 135 surface soil samples in the Kongterik Pasture Nature Reserve in Xinjiang, China. They used different algorithms to select the feature bands of SS and built inversion models using extreme learning machines (ELM), back-propagation neural networks (BPNN), and convolutional neural networks (CNN). The results showed that the accuracy of predicting SS varied among the modeling methods, with the CNN model performing the best. The optimal hybrid model for predicting SS was the SA-CNN model, which had an R-2 value of 0.79 and a RMSE value of 9.41 g kg(-1).
